meanings.definition: A word that remains unchanged in form when used in different grammatical contexts.
meanings.sent1: In English, 'sheep' is an aptote because it stays the same whether it's singular or plural.
meanings.sent2: The word 'fish' is an aptote, meaning it doesn't change whether you're talking about one fish or many fish.
meanings.sent3: The aptote 'deer' decided to keep its form no matter how many of its friends were around.
meanings.sent4: The aptote 'sheep' stood out in the sentence, refusing to alter its appearance.
meanings.sent5: The teacher used the aptote 'moose' to demonstrate a word that doesn't change form.

meanings.definition: A word that lacks inflectional endings.
meanings.sent1: The aptote 'sheep' doesn't have any extra endings to show if it's singular or plural.
meanings.sent2: When you say 'sheep,' you don't need to add anything else to show there's more than one - it's an aptote.
meanings.sent3: The aptote 'fish' was happy not to have to worry about any extra letters at the end.
meanings.sent4: The aptote 'deer' felt relieved not to deal with any additional endings in the sentence.
meanings.sent5: The aptote 'moose' proudly stood alone without any inflectional endings.
